linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 1 shows the location of the 19,000 Barnett shale play wells drilled between 2003 and 2016 by year, based on date of first production. The entire production history of the wells based on vintage and after shifting to time zero (normalized) is presented in Fig. 2.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Barnett shale play well locations from 2003 to 2016.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Barnett shale play well locations from 2003 to 2016.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 1 shows the location of the 19,000 Barnett shale play wells drilled between 2003 and 2016 by year, based on date of first production. The entire production history of the wells based on vintage and after shifting to time zero (normalized) is presented in Fig. 2.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Normalized monthly gas production, vintage year with numbers of wells.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Normalized monthly gas production, vintage year with numbers of wells.

linkTarget.anchoringText: A simple scatter plot between best 3-month gas rate (Mcf/D) and lateral length (ft) of all the wells (Fig. 3) shows that most of the wells are in the range of 1,500 to 4,800 ft of lateral length.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Best 3-month gas rate (Mscf/D) vs. lateral length (ft), Barnett shale play.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Best 3-month gas rate (Mscf/D) vs. lateral length (ft), Barnett shale play.

linkTarget.anchoringText: First, we plotted the scatter plot of the best 3-month gas rate versus lateral length in a violin plot (Fig. 4). A clear distribution can be seen based on the grouping of lateral lengths, and it seems to display an increasing trend. However, we must be cautious. The number of wells in the 8,000 to 12,000 ft group is much less than the number of wells in the <8,000-ft group. Nevertheless, the maximum rate seems to increase for longer lateral length wells. This raises the question of whether there is a sweet spot in terms of lateral length.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Violin plot of the best 3-month gas rate vs. lateral length (by group).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Violin plot of the best 3-month gas rate vs. lateral length (by group).

linkTarget.anchoringText: Superimposing total proppant volume by total fluid injection (lb/gal, shown as bubbles) onto a violin plot does not show much of a difference because most of the ratio data are in the 0.5 to 50 range (Fig. 5). This needs to be investigated further, but there is no critical observation that can be made for the entire field. Similarly, the number of fracturing stages versus lateral length was investigated in a violin plot (Fig. 6). Another display that is useful is the superposition of gross interval onto the lateral length violin plot (Fig. 7). We suspect that gross interval is directly proportional to longer lateral length because more reservoir is in contact with the well.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Violin plot of best 3 months gas rate vs. lateral length groups with total proppant/total fluid.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Violin plot of best 3 months gas rate vs. lateral length groups with total proppant/total fluid.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Superimposing total proppant volume by total fluid injection (lb/gal, shown as bubbles) onto a violin plot does not show much of a difference because most of the ratio data are in the 0.5 to 50 range (Fig. 5). This needs to be investigated further, but there is no critical observation that can be made for the entire field. Similarly, the number of fracturing stages versus lateral length was investigated in a violin plot (Fig. 6). Another display that is useful is the superposition of gross interval onto the lateral length violin plot (Fig. 7). We suspect that gross interval is directly proportional to longer lateral length because more reservoir is in contact with the well.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Violin plot of the best 3-month gas rate vs. lateral length group with number of fracturing stages.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Violin plot of the best 3-month gas rate vs. lateral length group with number of fracturing stages.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Superimposing total proppant volume by total fluid injection (lb/gal, shown as bubbles) onto a violin plot does not show much of a difference because most of the ratio data are in the 0.5 to 50 range (Fig. 5). This needs to be investigated further, but there is no critical observation that can be made for the entire field. Similarly, the number of fracturing stages versus lateral length was investigated in a violin plot (Fig. 6). Another display that is useful is the superposition of gross interval onto the lateral length violin plot (Fig. 7). We suspect that gross interval is directly proportional to longer lateral length because more reservoir is in contact with the well.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Violin plot best 3-month gas rate vs. lateral length group with gross interval.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Violin plot best 3-month gas rate vs. lateral length group with gross interval.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The scatter plots (Fig. 8) display cumulative gas production at 12 months versus lateral length with colors indicating the lateral length groups and sizes based on the above-mentioned normalized completion parameters. Note that all the selected wells for this operator belong in the same acreage area.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Scatter plots of cumulative gas production at 12 months vs. lateral length groups with normalized completion parameters for a major operator.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Scatter plots of cumulative gas production at 12 months vs. lateral length groups with normalized completion parameters for a major operator.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Compositional fluid used in the study is a typical volatile oil with a gas/oil ratio (GOR) of 1,600 scf/STB. Its phase envelope is shown in Fig. 9.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Phase envelope of the typical compositional fluid (GOR=1600 scf/STB) in the Eagle Ford condensate/oil area.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Phase envelope of the typical compositional fluid (GOR=1600 scf/STB) in the Eagle Ford condensate/oil area.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 10 indicates well production increases almost linearly as horizontal lateral length increases. Note that this comes with the assumptions of same quality rock and same completion quality in the additional lateral sections. Although the trend looks like a linear relationship in Fig. 10, we can observe variations in the increase in oil production (column 4 in Table 4) with different lateral length cases. For example, increasing the lateral length from 10,080 ft to 11,280 ft only resulted in an oil production increase of 133 bbl, but increasing the lateral length from 13,680 ft to 14,480 ft increased the accumulated oil production by 512 bbl.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Accumulated oil production vs. lateral length (scenario 1).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Accumulated oil production vs. lateral length (scenario 1).

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 11 illustrates the transient flowing behavior of the wells. It shows the trends in wellhead liquid flow rate for the shortest and longest lateral lengths. Both the shortest well and the longest well show slugging behaviors after 9 days simulation time. However, with a longer lateral and more fracture clusters, the 17,280-ft lateral well started with a much higher initial stable rate and was still producing at the end of the 17-day simulation period in contrast to the 4,168-ft lateral well.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Liquid flow rate at wellhead vs. time (scenario 1).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Liquid flow rate at wellhead vs. time (scenario 1).

linkTarget.anchoringText: We can see that the oil production increase per 1,200-ft lateral increase is declining from 1214 bbl to 670 bbl. This is because a higher rate results in higher pressure drop along the long lateral, which suppresses the reservoir inflow from the clusters close to the toe. We can see the same trend in Fig. 12. The trendline of the results can be fit to a linear curve. However, it is better described as a polynomial curve. This shows that in this scenario, the change in production increase declines as lateral length becomes longer.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Accumulated oil production vs. lateral length (scenario 2).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Accumulated oil production vs. lateral length (scenario 2).
